CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 30, 1950, pg. 5 reads: "Crime Lab On Wheels - In order to promote greater speed and efficiency in solving of crimes, the homicide squad of the police bureau, headed by Inspector Adam Giesler and Capt. Joseph Flynn, now has a special mobile laboratory which may be brought to the scene immediately following the report of any major crime. Included in the latest scientific equipment are facilities for finger prints, photography, paraffin tests, etc., so that the experts can begin work immediately.  The new unit was initiated last Saturday when a fatal stabbing took place on Townsend Street. Shown in the converted police wagon is Detective James Swide who worked on the case. - Harris Photo."Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 8, 1953, pg. 1, reads: "Exterior and Interior 'crime lab on wheels'...no one bothered to send for it."  Headline for accompanying article by Ralph E. Koger reads: "Lethargy, Bungling Charged In Rape-Killing Police Probe - 'Body Drag' Marks Lost; Investigators Failed to Call 'Lab on Wheels."
TitMainTitle: Detective James Swide standing in Pittsburgh Police mobile crime lab van with recording equipment and cameras
